p: Plants have great potential to provide chemoprotective effects against cancer and over 60 % of anti-cancer drugs are derived from natural sources including plants, microorganisms and marine organisms (Sultana et al., 2014[ 37]; Fridlender et al., 2015[ 11]; Dey et al., 2019[ 9]). Plant-derived anticancer drugs such as taxol from Taxus brevifolia L., camptothecin from Camptotheca acuminata, Decne., vinca alkaloids from Catharanthus roseus (L.) G. Don and podophyllotoxin from Podophyllum peltatum L. are well-known and extensively used in clinical trial (Iqbal et al., 2017[ 15]; Kuruppu et al., 2019[ 18]).
